I don't know what your original post said, as I am no longer a moderator, but I know that at least when I was one we cut a very hard line between calling out individuals versus groups.

Calling out individuals is a very clear case of naming a shaming, whereas calling out a group is different.
May I know why aren't you a mod anymore?

Sure, it mostly came down to stress + workload.

I became a mod shortly before starting college and after a couple months balancing the two started to become too hard.  I was only helping out a couple of tickets per week and there was a lot of stuff going on in the Moderation team at the time.  A big wash of changes that we enacted, lots of discussions about GD at the time, a bit of drama thrown into the mix as well. 

Basically I didn't have the time to devote enough of myself to moderation as I would have needed to to keep up with everything.  I was part of the first wave of the boards volunteers so I held on until we had pulled in and finished training a new wave (Think it was 3rd wave?) before pulling out in the quiet time that followed to cause minimal disturbance.

Never really announced it anywhere but I was never one of the super well known mods, especially since "back in my day" we had different mods for different sections of the boards.  I was part of Roaming so we took care of all the tiny boards like Mechs vs Minions & Player Recruitment so no one really notices when we vanish.  I actually think every other mod who was in Roaming with me has retired to "Veteran" status at this point.

is it really so stressfull to be a mod?

(It's not hard to not notice you with that name of yours :D)

Modding definitely has some stress attached to it, but it also depends on the position you are in.  As a member of Roaming there wasn't much stress put on by the community or queue values (Comparatively Mods in GD, Gameplay, and Memes&Games get a ton of community feedback, both good and bad while also having queues of tickets that can get _really_ backed up)

However just being a mod is kinda stressful and changes how you interact with everyone.  Just by virtue of your name being a different colour you have to watch what you say, play nice, moderate everything you see, and handle people asking questions you know nothing about.

So personally more of the stress came in due to watching how I interacted with the community than the difficulty of actually moderating.  It didn't help that my name has always been borderline rule breaking and I liked to chat a lot with people like Taric the Gay.  Stuff could get out of hand pretty quickly if people decided to take offense and having to retype everything I posted 5 times just to make sure I was as nice as possible made it difficult to stay engaged with the community.

-----------------------------

That being said actually moderating could be stressful too.  Redirecting posts in the wrong section (which is 90% of what Roaming had to deal with) is easy enough, but having to choose how to handle different situations while explaining why things aren't allowed isn't easy.  A single difficult post could take half an hour of figuring out how to explain things in a both polite and clear manner.  For the other roles I know there were times where over a hundred tickets would get backed up, and of course people would frequently request moderators on the Discord as well.  To top it all off we held (still hold maybe?) weekly meetings to discuss how to improve the boards as a whole.

I think that moderating in any position is always going to be stressful, especially when you are acting as the face of a major company but only have a single employee of said company that you can easily contact.

Based on the amount of turnover in the role I doubt I am the only mod that thinks this way.  Also just look at how many downvotes most pinned comments end up getting.  Entire threads get derailed to hate on some mods, even though mods are just here to help enforce the rules of the boards, something they do for free and without any expectation of thanks.  (Okay technically we all got the Riot ward so it isn't really for _free_.)
